history.content:
Hi! I haven't studied abroad (yet) but I've been accepted to one, and I've done extensive research on how major/breadth class requirements work and how to select classes :")) Essentially, as long as your host university allows you to take their CS courses, you're able to take those classes. For whichever university you choose, just check to see that the study abroad program allows you to take CS courses (some universities offer CS to normal students but not study abroad - some London universities for example). Some have pre-reqs but being an incoming junior, I think you should be fine. Generally culture/language/breadth classes are easy to get Berkeley credit for and are offered at most host universities without pre-reqs.

The main concern would be if those classes transfer to major requirements, but you mentioned that's not a problem, so you should be good to go! If you would like to get some requirements out of the way, you can check out this link for some pre-approved courses, this page for any other info and how to submit a course for evaluation to satisfy a requirement.

Sorry I can't offer more specific feedback, but it really does vary greatly depending on the program. I'd recommend speaking to the dedicated Berkeley Study Abroad advisor for your target area (China).

children.subject:
I think for most locations, it's based on whether or not you meet the requirements, so non-competitive. But you're right in that it differs by country/location. For example, London universities like UCL and I think KCL are quite competitive and take a limited number of students. There's also "impacted" programs, which means that demand exceeds supply (Japan for example has impacted programs). I think China should be ok since there's no impacted section here: https://myapp.berkeley.edu/uceap/advisingnotes/china.pdf This advising guide might be helpful for other topics too, but right now it still has all the Covid cancellations :(

I don't know if things might somehow be different for UCLA (even though I'm assuming it's through UCEAP) so make sure your friend checks too! Glad to be of help :D

@student response Thanks, that was super helpful! Just curious, how competitive is it to get into a study abroad program (and does the competitiveness differ by country/location)? My friend from UCLA and I were actually both hoping to study abroad at the same university in Fall 2022 so I was wondering how hard it would be for both of us to be accepted.

history.content: Hi, I'm a rising junior CS major and I was planning on studying abroad in Fall 2022 (mainly looking at a university in China). When studying abroad, would I be able to take that university's EECS/CS classes or would it mainly be cultural/language classes? Graduating on time is not a concern as I will basically only need 1-2 classes after my junior year to graduate. Would love to hear from anyone who has studied abroad as an EECS/CS major. Thanks!
